tip: Did you consider developing a specific research question?
Did you seek advice from a statistical expert before analyzing your data?
Would others interpret the data they same way you do?
Do you have enough data to arrive at a reasonable conclusion?
Have you engaged a domain expert to be sure you understand the data?
Do you understand the assumptions made by the statistical analysis?
Did you consider the functional dependencies in your data?
Is the level of aggregation data aggregation appropriate?
Can you assess the internal and ecological validity of these results?
Have you accounted for the presence of hidden confounders in your data?
Could you reproduce these results at a later date?
Does your data have any quality issues?
Did you use deep learning when logistic regression would have sufficed?
Have you considered alternative interpretations of these results?
Do you know what the uncertainty is in these results?
Have you considered potential sources of bias in your data collection?
Have you considered how likely is it that these results are due purely to chance?
Are you mistaking a correlative relationship for a causal one?
Have you considered whether there is missing data?
How representative is your data sample relative to the population it was drawn from?
Are you applying a consistent criteria for analyzing your results?
Have you considered the role of seasonality or intrasample correlation in your data?
